body: @mboehm7 - I believe the `unitary`, `orthogonality` and `reproduction` of matrix `A`, will be sufficient to verify the operation. However, I have some I/O problems with the scripts. The only output matrix is `D`. Please help me resolve syntax issues, as c++ is language of expertise.
I made a merge commit rather than rebase because there were a lot of conflicts in the PlanSelection file. This should be good to go. Let me know if you prefer a squash.

Well, I actually like to get the statistics for failed runs. This gives you at least some hints if the script failed on the first iteration or later, which is useful for debugging OOMs, memory leaks, and leaks of temporary variables with files in the scratch_space.

LGTM - thanks @dhutchis. Overall this is an excellent addition. There are still some minor issues (micro opt, stats formatting, and stats collection) but it's probably easier to modify this the next time I touch it.
@mboehm7 - i shall close this PR then.
for the future: I just expressed my personal opinion here but it was still up for discussion - if there is a good reason, we can change anything.

Thanks for working on this @feihugis. I hate to say it after you've already done the work but I think that this change would actually be counter-productive for performance in most cases. For example, consider the scripts for bivariate or univariate statistics. Normally, each remote worker would read the dataset once and then slice out individual columns in-memory. In contrast, with this change each column indexing would effectively read and deserialize the entire dataset, which could easily lead to slowdowns of orders of magnitude. Note that the proposed subset readers still read and deserialize all blocks. 

However, you're right that there are scenarios where we currently perform unnecessary reads. To understand these, let me give you a little bit of background: (1) You don't have to worry about OOMs because these in-memory indexing instructions are only compiled if the input and output fits into memory of the given context (driver or remote executors). (2) If the data is partitionable (row/column/batch) and does not fit into memory, we apply automatic partitioning, which allows to read individual partitions (see readMatrixPartition in MatrixObject). (3) By default, these partitions are created (locally or by a Spark job), materialized on HDFS, and read by remote workers. However, there is also a fused datapartition-execute Spark job, that partitions your data on-the-fly and executes the parfor body on each partition - there are special constraints but it should apply here (and that's what we eventually want to achieve for this script). I think there are multiple underlying issues that prevent us from compiling this right now (e.g., unknown batch sizes, forced execution, etc)

Moving forward, I would recommend to address the following two major things, which would actually improve performance of a whole lot of scripts: 
1) Improve parfor block indexing analysis [1]: Once, the parfor optimizer can identify (and guarantee) a constant batch size for the batch indexing expressions, a lot of problems (including the need to force any specific execution strategies) will go away.  
2) Parfor broadcast exploitation [2]: Coming back to the actual read issue. Indeed right now each worker reads shared inputs redundantly. The right way to address this in the general case is to send these inputs via broadcast variables to the executors, which transfer the data just once for all tasks to each executor. In order to do that, we need to know all memory estimates (see 1) because we would need to ensure that we can pin this shared variable into memory and still execute all other operations (with its inputs and output). This would help all scenarios that are not amenable to partitioning (data is small enough to fit in each executor).
3) Data Locality: One issue with data partitioning is that the parfor tasks might not run on the same node where their input data resides. Our MapReduce backend addresses this via explicit data locality, where we created a custom wrapper file splits that mapped iterations to partitions and reported the nodes where these partitions reside. We could extend our Spark parfor backend with a similar technique. This would help all scenarios where we apply partioning but the fused dataparittion-execute does not apply.

We want to do these things for a while now, so its probably a good idea to get it done right now. If you'd like to take these over, I'm happy to assist; otherwise I will make some time for them in the next weeks. 

[1] https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1782
[2] https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1313

I would recommend to start from the existing Kmeans script [1], preserve the matricized distance and centroid computation, and maybe simply wrap a train and predict function around it, and start any additional refactoring from there.  

Also it's generally a good idea to vectorize your computations: For example, loops like "parfor (i in 1:n) arr[i,1] = i" become arr[1:n,1]=t(seq(1,n)) which in turn becomes arr = t(seq(1,n)).


[1] https://github.com/apache/systemml/blob/master/scripts/algorithms/Kmeans.dml

Sure, sorry for the formatting and micro opt trouble.  It's hard to resist the urge to "fix" something I notice while touching the code.  I recognize now that these "fixes" cause more trouble than they are worth, at this stage of development.
don't worry @dhutchis  - we appreciate your contributions.

Thanks for your detailed explanation, @mboehm7! It helps me get the whole picture of SystemML. I'm glad to work on the two issues. Your assistance will be definitely helpful.

For the subset reading, I double check the source code of Hadoop Sequence File Reader. You are right. `org.apache.hadoop.io.SequenceFile.Reader#next(org.apache.hadoop.io.Writable)` still needs to read the whole block, even though it skips the value. 

I will start to work on SYSTEMML-1782.
@nakul02 could you please review. I have tested this fix on my local system.

@mboehm7 - sir, I have overridden squareness test. Other than that we are good to go.

@j143 Yeah, it would be good to reuse optimizers just like we are reusing the layers.   The stochastic optimizers (SGD, RMSprop, Adam, etc.) are already modularized in the [`nn` library](https://github.com/apache/systemml/tree/master/scripts/nn/optim).  The ALS algorithm is still written in a command line form.  I would recommend that we start with SGD & friends, and later we can add ALS.
Can you provide an example for regression, classification, and ranking i.e, how `i/o` format looks like. Thanks.

The following DML:
```
a=min();
```

previously gave:
```
ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: 0
```
